{{ja-readings
|goon=おう<あう, おく<をく
|kanon=いく<ゐく, おう<あう

|nanori=くま, おお, おん, つ, のく

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|おく}}
Despite the apparent overlap with the modern [[呉音#Japanese|''goon'']] reading of ''oku'' that is derived from {{cog|ltc|-}}, this term is actually rooted in {{der|ja|ojp|-|sort=おく}}, appearing in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'' collection of poetry dating to roughly 759 CE. Cognate with {{m|ja|沖|tr=oki|t=the open sea, offshore}}, originally in reference to “somewhere far removed, possibly out of sight”. While ''oki'' came to mean “far removed in the wide open → far off shore”, ''oku'' instead came to mean “far removed inside → inside, interior”.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|おく}}

# [[inside]]; [[inner]] [[depth]]s
# [[back]], [[rear]]
# inside the house
# one's [[heart]], true feelings
